snippet.title: Woz on 'Jobs': No, just no
snippet.description: In a review posted to Gizmodo, Steve Wozniak calls Ashton Kutcher "disingenuous" and believes the new movie is wildly inaccurate.

snippet.title: Kanye, the new Steve Jobs, gets Jobs-signed Apple mouse
snippet.description: Kim Kardashian, good friend of Steve Wozniak, gives her beau lovely Apple Pro mice signed by Jobs and Woz. They are a Father's Day gift.

snippet.title: Intel to ax 1,500 jobs in Costa Rica
snippet.description: The chipmaker's closure of a Costa Rice assembly-and-test operation is part of a plan to cut costs and shift Intel's focus from PCs to mobile.

snippet.title: Steve Jobs biopic pops up on Netflix
snippet.description: "Jobs", starring Ashton Kutcher as Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, is now available on Netflix in the US.

snippet.title: Wozniak on Jobs film: 'There were a lot of things wrong'
snippet.description: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak has seen the Jobs biopic, and he isn't best pleased.

snippet.title: Steve Jobs reportedly thought TVs a 'terrible business'
snippet.description: Before resigning as CEO, the Apple co-founder told key employees that he didn't think Apple should get into the business because of its poor margins, according to a new book.

snippet.title: Ludicrous Steve Jobs statue was nothing to do with Apple
snippet.description: Apple wasn't even aware of the competition which saw a statue unveiled to commemorate its late CEO Steve Jobs.

snippet.title: Obama's commerce secretary to petition Silicon Valley on jobs
snippet.description: Secretary Penny Pritzker will meet with LinkedIn CEO Jeff Weiner on Monday, and Facebook and others after that.

snippet.title: Steve Jobs evidence latest battleground in Silicon Valley's no-hire case
snippet.description: Plaintiffs in a class-action lawsuit against Apple, Google, Intel, and Adobe say they should be able to use all Jobs-related evidence to make their case.

snippet.title: Tech giants want Steve Jobs' personality out of wage-fixing suit
snippet.description: Apple, Google, Intel, and Adobe Systems argue that the Apple co-founderâ€™s temperament should not be fair game in the upcoming class-action trial.
